message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a diagnosis of Angelman syndrome, and among the options, only microdeletion of maternal 15q11-q13 is associated with this syndrome. The wide-based stance and difficulty standing suggest ataxia, and the increased muscle tone and deep tendon reflexes suggest spasticity, which are common findings in Angelman syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of seizures, happy demeanor, and developmental delay suggest the diagnosis of Angelman syndrome. This is caused by a microdeletion of maternal 15q11-q13, which is the most likely mechanism to explain these findings. MECP2 gene mutation is associated with Rett syndrome, which can also cause developmental delay, but usually presents with loss of milestones and hand stereotypies. The other options are not associated with Angelman syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient demonstrates symptoms consistent with Angelman syndrome, which is associated with a microdeletion of maternal 15q11-q13. MeCP2 gene mutations are associated with Rett syndrome. Microdeletions of paternal 15q11-q13 can result in Prader-Willi syndrome, which would not explain the symptoms seen in the patient. Microdeletion of 22q11.2 is associated with DiGeorge syndrome, which would also not explain the symptoms seen in the patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of seizures, happy demeanor, developmental delay, and specific physical features is highly suggestive of Angelman syndrome, and among the options, only microdeletion of maternal 15q11-q13 is associated with Angelman syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of seizures, inappropriate laughter, developmental delay, and growth abnormalities suggests a diagnosis of Angelman syndrome. The genetic cause of Angelman syndrome is a microdeletion of maternal 15q11-q13. All other options are associated with different conditions such as Prader-Willi syndrome (microdeletion of paternal 15q11-q13), Rett syndrome (MECP2 gene mutation), and DiGeorge syndrome (microdeletion of 22q11.2).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Angelman syndrome. Among the options, only microdeletion of maternal 15q11-q13 is associated with Angelman syndrome. The wide-based stance and mandibular prognathism are characteristic physical features of the disease. Muscle tone is increased in all extremities and deep tendon reflexes are exaggerated, which are also common findings in Angelman syndrome. MECP2 gene mutation is associated with Rett syndrome, which presents with head growth deceleration, loss of hand skills, and poor coordination. Microdeletion of paternal 15q11-q13 is associated with Prader-Willi syndrome, which presents with craving for food, hypogonadism, and obesity. Microdeletion of 22q11.2 is associated with DiGeorge syndrome, which presents with congenital heart disease and immune deficiency.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The characteristic symptoms of unprovoked laughter, happy demeanor, and developmental delay suggest Angelman syndrome, which is caused by a microdeletion of maternal 15q11-q13. The other options are associated with different conditions, such as Prader-Willi syndrome (microdeletion of paternal 15q11-q13), Rett syndrome (MECP2 gene mutation), and DiGeorge syndrome (microdeletion of 22q11.2).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest Angelman syndrome, which is caused by a microdeletion on the maternal chromosome at 15q11-q13. MECP2 gene mutation is associated with Rett syndrome, which has different symptoms. Microdeletion of paternal 15q11-q13 is associated with Prader-Willi syndrome, which also has different symptoms. Microdeletion of 22q11.2 is associated with DiGeorge syndrome, which also has different symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms including seizures, unprovoked laughter, developmental delay, abnormal gait, and mandibular prognathism suggest Angelman syndrome. Angelman syndrome is caused by a microdeletion of maternal 15q11-q13. MECP2 gene mutation causes Rett syndrome, which does not present with the symptoms described. Microdeletion of paternal 15q11-q13 can cause Prader-Willi syndrome, which presents with hypotonia and feeding difficulties. Microdeletion of 22q11.2 can cause DiGeorge syndrome, which presents with congenital heart defects, cleft palate, and immunodeficiency.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The child presents with features of Angelman syndrome, which is most commonly caused by microdeletion of maternal 15q11-q13. This deletion leads to loss of UBE3A gene function. MECP2 gene mutations are associated with Rett syndrome. Microdeletion of paternal 15q11-q13 is associated with Prader-Willi syndrome. Microdeletion of 22q11.2 is associated with DiGeorge syndrome.
